p.s: I am writing this letter to you, on the note that I heard from one of your students that The Hate U Give got banned in your school and think that this is big mistake on your behalf.

Banning this book not only keeps the students of your school from learning about the important topics of police brutality, racism and other discrimination in society in the USA, but also makes students think that activism and standing up against discrimination is wrong.
This also will strengthen racism in the society and especially their generation.
The excuses for banning the book are not even logical.
The vulgar and offensive language is partially AAVEAfrican-American Vernacular English, ana dialect of the African-American community, and also normal street and teenage language.
This is the racism depicted in the book shown through a real life example.
The sexual references are nothing more than making out or kissing, which is completely normal for teenagers and also shown in tons of other books.
It is also shown through these scenes what consent and personal boundaries are.
An example is the scene where Starr and her boyfriend are making out, but Starr does not want to go further so they do not.
Even though they have a conflict about it, they solve it through talking.
The depicted drug use mentioned is in all forms shown as bad and not wanted, but it shows the real experiences in those communtiescommunities and how they have to live.
At last all the negative light the police are shown in, just resemble real life experiences.
All these things are shown in a way the reader can understand what black people go through and how systemic racism is a thing happening.
StarrsStarr's character development is a great example for many, especially teenagers.
Robbing them of that is stopping them from growing confident and being themselves and standing up for exactly that.
Also is it extremely racist of banning a book of ana black author describing her experiences as a black teen.
